div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET
div.p: The deplorable incident which has led to the deaths of so many English fishermen is a striking example of the hopeless state to which the morale of the Russians has been reduced by the successes of the Japanese. The only excuse which the Russian Government can bring forward to partially palliate what is nothing more nor less than a case of murder on the high seas, is that it was inspired by the fear ofJapanese mines. It is almost ineredible that the commanders of the Russian men-of-war- could have beeri so panie-stricken as to fail to distingish the humble craft of fishermen, whether steam or sail, for all fishing vessels are distinguished~ by international signals, which are known to , all sea-faring men. Both by night and day these signals are distinguishable, and their use is enforced by the Board of Trade in order that passing ships may keep clear of their nets. Our telegrams expressly state that the Hull trawlers were carrying: these signals when they were so unwarrantably attacked. The outrage took place at night, when the signals are a red and white light, and as the Russians put their searchlights on the trawlers, it is .. incredible that they failed to notice the signals, more especially as they must have been aware that they were approaching the North Sea fishing grounds. The indigna. tion at home owing to the trgie deaths of these unfortunate . fishermen, while. engaged in their peaceful pursuits, must be intense, and unless the Russian Go- vernment takes immediate steps, to give full satisfaction for the outrage, publie feeling may be roused to a most dan- gerous pitch. An official telegram this morning states that urgent representa- tions have been addressed to the Russian Government at St. Peteraburg, where it has been explained that the situation, in. the. opinion of his Majusty's Govern- ment, does not admit of any delay. .To day there will- be a conference be- tween Lord .Lansdowne . and Count Ben. kendorif, the Russian Ambassador, : and it is to be Hoped that tha fullest compensa. tion will be offered by. the Taar's repre- sentative for one of the most deplorable errors of judgment that has ever oceurred in the history of modern warfare.

div.head: MILITARY PRISONS.
div.p: Any reform which improves the. lot of the soldier is ofbenetit to the community at large, and this more especially in Egypt, where compulsory service obtains. Accord. ing to a recently. published report. by Lieutenant-Colonel Henderson upon mili- tary prisons in England, it would appest that the change of method adopted in the treaiment of soldiers convicted of offences is most favorably spoken of by governors' and prison chaplains. Under the : newly. inaugurated system prisoners are made to continue their military training and to perform a good deal of useful work, with the result that they leave prison better soldiers and better men. The' military authorities in this country; alwvays zealour to increase the efficiency of the natire army under their charge, may be. recom- mended to study this report with a view to introducing into Egypt a systom which has been found to work so satisfactorily in England.

div.head:
NORTH SEA OUTRAGE.
BLUNDER DUE TO PANIC.
SERIOUS SITUATION.
ACTION OF H.M. GOVERNMENT

div.p: The juipers consider , the North Sea outrag Shave beenp blunder dne to panig, bu zdnimously insist upon the Government taking fnu, setion in the matter, and demanding an iniddiate m dlogy, reparation, and.the punish sent of the culprits. It is pointed out that the most gerious aspect of the' incident is the faet tint the fleet steamed at full speed without atfempting to rescue the crews of the sunken beffs and -withont reporting the affair any where on the English coast.
The Standard demands the immediate recall of the Baltic Fleet, which will otherwise become an intemnational nuisance. .

It appears that the Baltic Fleet dreaded an attack in the North' Sea, the Rassian Prees having been full of the wildest stories of the Japanese plans for exploding torpedoes lashed to fisbing boats, ete. The fishermen declare that the fleet approached very close to them, and that searchlights showed :the fren' workipg at thie fish. 'Moreover, the trawlers displayed the international fishing lights.

It was annolnced in -Hull yesterday at mid- tight that the trawler Wren had been sunk with all on board. It was stated there are 29 woaniled on board the Mission vessel, which is itill at sea. 'Certain boats are yet miseing. According to sundry accounts, the fishing fleet numbered 150.
(Reuter.)

Lord Lansdowne will see Count Benkendorff, the Rndsian Ambassador, to-morrow.
It is anderstood that the Russian explana- fion is that there waw reason to fear a Japanese mine attack.
(Reuter.)
Soveral vesseln of the Russian Fleet have arrived and left ugain after being provisioned. (Havas.)
A telegrain from St. Petersburg says that all was qnigs on the night from. the 22nd to the 23d inst:

div.p: Marshal Oyama repotts that the total.num- ber of:Russfan dend discovered after the battle' of the Sha-Ho amounted . to-13,333. The Drisoners are,709.
(Reuiter.)

div.head: DEATH OF LADY DILKE
div.p: Lady Dilke is dead. (Reutet).

Emilia Frances Dilke, who was a daughter of the late Colonel Strong, of the Madras army, mafried first, in 1862, the Rev. Mark Pattison (who died on July 30, 1884), Rector of Lincoln College, Oxford; and seoond, in 1885, the, Right, Hon. Sir .Charles. Wentworth - Dilke, Bavt. Lady Dilke . was long a writer in the Sitarday and Westminster Reciews, and after- wards became, for some time, fine-art eritic of the Aoidemy. In 1879 Lady Dilke published, through Kegan Panl, Trench and Co., a work in two voluikes, illustrated by herself, and entitled The Renaissance of Art in France." In 1884 ile published, in French, through the Librairie de l Art, a monograph on Claude. In 1886 she peblished; through Routledge and Sons, "The Shiring of Death,".a volume of stories. In 1888 te published, through Chapman and Hall, "Art in the Modern State." In 1888, 89, '90 the contribinted several archaic stories to the Caiwersal Reriew, and wrote in the Fortnightly Iterien and the New Rectew on Trades Unions for Women, in which she took a deep interest. lady Dilke since published "Shrine of Love and other Stories," 1891; "French Painters of the Eighteonth Century,"1899;"French Architects. ail Sculptors of the Eighteenth "Century," 1300;"French Decoration and Furniture in du. Eighteenth Century,"* 1901; "French Egravers and Draughtsmen of the Eighteenth Century." The late Lady Dilke was an active member of the Committee. of the Women's Trade Union League, for which she has freiuently spoken.

div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea. Central position. Under English Management. 31-11-904

div.p: no longer exists in Egypt

div.p: THe Finance Ministry received 75 cases of new silver coin yesterday

div.p: Fifty three new cafets have been admitteed to the Military School at Abbassieh

div.head: Theft of Hy,m Books-
div.p: 50 Hymn books and a small bell have been stolen from the American Chrch at Rawda, Cairo.

div.p: found in Khalifa district of Cairo during the night of the 26th ins. will be poisened by the police

div.head: New Doctors-
div.p: Messrs/ High R. Magill, Jean Kerrasotis, and Edouard Archarouni have ben authorised to practice as doctors in Egypt

div.head: PRINCE LINE .-
div.p: The S.S. Sailor Prince (4,650 tons), one of the latest additions to the Prince Line, arrived in harbour this, morning on her first visit to Alexandria.

div.head: DENTAL SURGEON. -
div.p: Mr. Shellard, dental surgeon, 22, Rosetta-street, Alexandria, has resumed the usual winter hours at his surgery: 9 a.m. to 1 p.m: and 3 to 5.p.m.

div.head: FIRE .-
div.p: The loss occasioned by the fire which broke out on Sunday, eyening >in the chair factory belonging to-Messrs. Abram and Matta- tia,is estimated at 27,000 francs. The insurance covers 120,000 francs.

div.head: ARMY SCHOOLS. -
div.p: The Inspector of Army Schools, Mediterranean District (Lieut. Cook), arrived here on Saturday last and is remaining at Alexandria on duty during the present week, after which he proceeds to Cairo.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL POLICE .-
div.p: Kaimakam Melville Bey, Commandant of the Suez Canal Police, has been appointed inspector in the Ministry of the Interior, being replaced by Kaimakam T. A. Schalch Bey in the command of the Canal Police.

div.head: SUEZ CANAL .-
div.p: On the 20th inst., 15 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 10. were British, 1 Dutch, 1 German, 1 Austrian, 1 Russian, and 1 Spanish. The transit and passenger dues for the day amounted to 444,540.58.frs. The total transit and pas- senger dues collected from the Ist to that date on 255 vessels amounted to 6,603,396.24 frs.

div.head: SAN STEFAND LOTTERY .-
div.p: The first prize of 1,000 frs. in Sunday's drawing was won by the holder of ticket No. 7831, the' second of 100 frs. by ticket No. 6855. Nos. 1086 and 6652 each gained 50 frs., and the holders of the following tickets are entitled to 25 frs. each ;-- Nos. 779 $836; 1848; 9135; 6870; 5012; 8636 9109 ; 8000 5497; 1910; 2288. The first prize of 1,000 frs. at the previous drawing was won by Mr. Carmello Vella.

div.head: LORD KITCHENER'S COAT-OF-ARMS .-
div.p: Refer-, ring to the fact that many people are turning their attention to heraldry at the present time, and especially in.connection with book-plates, a writer in the New York Herald (Paris edition) says: "I was shown one recently which had been executed for Lord Kitchener when he was made a peer,. It is rather interesting to find that the late Queen allowed him to use the Union Jack crossed with the Egyptian flag, while his supporters dre a pair of camels ; he is also allowed the head of-an elephant."

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE
div.p: Sardou and Nagac's comedy Divorcons was given last night at the Alhambra Theatre. The performance was excellent in every respect. Mlle Blanche d'Orange was delightful as the heroine of the piece, and . her aternations of feeling towards her hosband and her lover were given with a very fine display. of acting. M. Moreau, as the husband, and M. de Prefonds as the lover, were both good.
To-night, Monsieur Badui and Monsiour Alphonse will be given.
To-morrow, the company will give Brieux's Les . Avaries. This piece, which evoked so much polemical discussion at the time of its first performance in France, conveys a thorough- ly moral lesson.

div.head: EDEN MUSIC HALL
div.p: The programme at the Eden Music-hall contains a rapid succession of good "turns" and there is absolutely no "lag" whatever. No one ought to miss seeing the performance of the Bourguit-Brocca couple. These , dancers execute some wonderful feats in the art of Terpsichore. In the "valse Tourbillon" and "valse Berceuse,". Mme Bourguit-Brocca dis- plays the inost fascinating grace of action and lightness of movement .. As for the muscular power of MrsBourguit-Brocca, it is simply phenominal, and he keeps dancing, twisting and lifting his companion with remarkable grace. Mlle Rosensteel, one of the latest Freneh "stars," is a great success. Her voice and diction are bewitehing, especially so in the romance "Lorsque les lampions s'eteignent." Mrs. Darcier, as a flower girl, is excellent, as is Miss Mantes, the new "eccentric" singer. In fact, all the artisti are specially selected for one attraction or another, and much praise is due to the manager, Mr. Parissis, for his suc- cessful endeavours to entertain the public.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive returned yesterday from Mariont to Montazah, where his .Highness is spending the day.
On Sunday next the Khedive will pay a. visit to the Chrysanthemum Show at San Stefano .-

div.head: DECORATIONS.
div.p: Decerations have been conferred by H.H. the Khedive upon the following officials on.the occasion of their retirement :-
M. A. Cheridjian, Inspector of. Telegraphs, is promoted to the grade of Bey (Sanieh).e.

Ali Bahgat Effendi, former head of the , bu- rean of control of the Railway Administration, and Hassancin . Mohamed Effendi, 1st class clerk at the burean, de comptabilite at the Ministry of Finance, are promoted to the grade of Salisah (Pasha).

div.head: MERSA MATROUH PORT.
div.p: The construction of the new port at Mersa Matrouh has begun.' Messrs. Almagia have obtained the contract for the work.

div.head: TURKISH METHODS.
div.p: Up. to now no satisfactory explanation has been received' with regard to the representa- tions whiclr have been made to the Ottoman Government by the Postmaster-General . con- cerning the disappearance of 27 registered letters despatched from .Cairo to, Beyrout. Rresumably, some employés at Beyrout have wearied of waiting for their pay and have spoiled. the Egyptians. We recommend any ofour readers who have at any time to send letters containing anything of value to Syria to forward it through the French Post Office.

div.head: POLYTECHNIC SCHOOL.
div.p: A project for increasing the pay of engineers, who have passed successfully through the Polytechnic School and are entering upon their duties upder the Government, from L.E. 8 to L.E. 12-per month, is believed to be under discussion. It is to be hoped that it will be found practicable to raise their pay. The successful pupils of the Schools of Law and' Medicine turn to a great extent to private practice. From this the Government engineer is, of course, debarred: the pay, at starting though fair, is not high enough to attract large numbers of able young Egyptians to what is, from the national point of view, the most important profession in Egypt .. ..

div.head: NEW. SECONDARY SCHOOL.
div.p: It is rumoured that a third secondary school may be started at Cairo in the next financial year. Nothing, however, seems to be definitely known about the subject.

div.head: PORT SAID P. O. FRAUDS.
div.p: Abdel Maksud Effendi, cashier at the Port Said Post Office, was arraigned before the Native Appeal Court on the charge of appro- priating L.E. 887 belonging to the Pest Office to his own use. "The prisoner had been brought up before the Zagazig Tribunal and acquitted on the 10th July last.

In the Appeal Court, the prisoner accused his chief, Mr. Mancantelli, Postmaster at Port Said, who has been a respected onicial of the. Administration for the last 40 - years, of being the author of the robbery.
The Court exonerated Mr. Mancantetli of all. blame in the matter and sentenced Abdel Maksud Effendi to one year's imprisonment, to. make good the losses, and" to deprivation of his pension.

div.head: CATTLE PLAGUE.
div.p: One new locality is deelared infected with cattle plague to-day, i.e., Kell Rozan, in the Belbeis district.

div.head: MOTOR CONTRAVENTIONS.
div.p: The Cairo Traffic Police have drawn up contraventions at the Mixed Courts against the following gentlemen (proprietors of motor cars) for not carrying lights at the back of their machines r-Mr. Antoine Trehaki, .Mr. John Zoucas, Mr. Alexander Skynder, and Mr. G. Loukaitis,-

div.head: ESBEKIEH THEATRE.
div.p: "FAUNT" AND "LA TRAVIATA." :

On Saturday night Faust was given with success on. the whole. Signa. Marchesi-Coniglio acted well as Marguerite, but Signor Carpi's voice was too youthful in its inflections for the hoary-headed Faust of the 1st act, while in' the garden scene he showed rather a senile want of feryour in his acting. Sig. Vecchioni and, Pompa sang well and acted their melodra- matic parts with success, . but we were not hn- pressed by Signa. Zawner as Siebel.' The orchestra was excellent.

On Sunday La Traviata was given, with excellent singing -and acting by the baritone Sig. Modesti, who was. a thorouga success. Signa. Agostino sang well, though inctined to. be harsh in her higher notes. The othera work- ed hard but were put in the shade by Sig. Modesti, whose phrasing and clearness of enunciation were especially good.

div.head:
GOVERNMENT LANDS
IMPORTANT ANNOUNCEMENT.
div.p: We are authorised to state that the Finance Ministry ·has decided to discontinue the sale of. Government land until after.the 31st March next. The very numerous applications already received will then be considered in order of priority, and definite answers given. The above decision. does not apply to the sale of land in small plots, or for building purposes.

div.head: RAILWAY COAL CONTRACT.
div.p: The contract for. the supply' of two hundred and thirty thousand, four hundred and twenty tons of Welsh coal dnring the year 1905 for the Egyptian Stafe Railways has been decided between Messrs. Milburn and Messrs. Watts .Watts.

div.head: KHARTOUM WITHOUT MOSQUITOES.
div.p: Khartoum has been cleared of the mosquit pest and danger. This is one of the results of Dr. Balfour's work in the new laboratory. Fo the last eight months Khartoum has been rid of the pestilent insect. This means not only new comfort to the community, but immunity from malaria." In the first place.it has been established that the mosquito at Khartoum is malaria-bearing. ,It is, indeed, held to be the cause of all the malaria of the .country. Dr. Balfour has attacked it in the breeding-places. These are found in stagnant wells of which there are 700. These have been treated with crude petroleum, which affects their. public utility only for two or three days, but keeps them clear of mosquitoes for a month, Steamers are stopped a mile and a half from Khartoum and thoroughly disinfected, all their bilge- water, which is the prolific racruiting-ground of the creature, being treated with petroleum.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High.Commissioner, accompanied by his civil and military household, will leave Alexandtia for Cairo, as already announced, on Thursday. The special train conveying his Excellency and suite will leave Hadra station at 9.30 a.m. and arrive at Cairo at 1.55 p.m.

It is stated in the home papers that Lord and Lady Londesborough are going to the Riviera for the winter. This is only partly true, as Lord Londesborough himself intends wintering at Cairo, though it is just possible he may go as far as the South of France with Lady Londesborough and their children.
H. E. Boutros Pasha Ghali, Baron von Trauttenberg, Sir William Garstin, Mr. Vincent Corbett, Mr. Mcllwraith, and Chawarby Pasha called at the British Agency yesterday morning.
M. de la Bouliniere is expected to return on the 3rd November.
Lord Farrer and Mr. and Mrs. Bury arrive early in November. and have secured rooms at the Grand Continental.
The marriage between Mr. George B. Mao- pherson Grant, Sudan Agent at Alexandria, and Miss Dorothy E. Kellie MacCallum will take place in London towards the end or November.
Mr. Hugh Blomfield, son of Rear Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, has been appointed as inspector in the Finance Ministry. He is detailed for special work for two years in the Direction des Immeubles.
The salary of Captain Lyons, Director of Surveys at the Ministry of Public Works, is to be increased to £1,400 per annum.
So far as is settled, after a short honey moon at Combe, Mr. Bradley Martin and his bride will come to Egypt for the winter.
Lady Rogers has booked her passage by the P. and 0. S.S. Victoria, which leaves London on Friday ..
Dixon Bey is returning from leave by the same steamer, which is also bringing out Lord Farrer and Miss E. Gorst. :

The following are among the passengerswho are dueby the P.and O, S.S. Moldaviaat Port Said to-day :- Mr. and Mrs. E. B. Thubron,. Mr. C. E. Gaze, Mrs. Chinn, Mrs. Matchett, Captain Morant, Mrs. Fielding, Mr. T. H. Clowes, Mt. and Mrs. Hesketh-Pembroke, Mr. and Mrs. Alexandroff, infant and nurse, Mr. E. Bramall, Mr. S. de Bilinaki, Bimbashi H. L, Fell, Mr. Somers Clarke, Dr. A. J. M. Bentley.

Mr. P. R. Boxwell, of the Irrigation Depart- ment; is also due to arrive at Port Said by the P. and O.S.S. Moldavia to-day, on' return from leave. Mr. Boxwell; it will be remembered, was to have been the "best man" at the -nuptials of Mr. McCalman and the daughter of the Lord Mayor of London.

Mrs. and Miss Allan Joseph have booked passages for Port Said by the P. and O. S.S. Egypt, which leaves Marseilles on Friday next.
The Rev. A. H. Sayoe is coming out by the same steamer, as also are Dr. and Mrs. J. E. Cresswell, of Suez.

Mr. 'A. Biddulph Middleton and party, who were some years ago at the old Continental, are coming out this year, and have engaged rooms at the Grand Continental Hotel. They arrive on the 26th inst. to spend the winter in Egypt.
Mr. W. Dunbar Kilburn, who has for many years spent the winter at the Grand Continent- al, will arrive there again on the 8th Novem -. ber.
Mr. and Mrs. H. R. Newman have left She- pheard's Hotel to join their dahabenh Hapi and propose spending the winter in Nubia ..
Mr .. and Mrs. Cantel Bey have booked by the Bibby S.S. Warwickshire leaving Liverpool on the 24th' proxo.

div.head:
LA MORT DU SULTAN MOURAD
REVELATIONS
div.p: Nons sommes heureux de pouvoir offrir a nos lecteura la primeur de quelques rer- seignements inédite sur un des évécements les plas mystérieux de notre époque, ema- nant d'un des pertonnages les plus en vue de la capitale de l'empire ottoman.
Constantinople, le 5 ostobre, 1904.

Les journaaz d'Earope ont presque tous' consacre quelques lignes à ls mort da Sal- tan Mourad. L'article le plas remarquable a ete sans contredit celui du Times. Tracer ici les scenes de la vie de l'ex-Saltan Mou- rad depasserait le cadre restreint d'un joarnal. Nous dirons' qaelques mots sbale- ment pour. rappeler aumonde civiliee la haine dont il aete poursuivi jasqa'apres sa mort par son frete Hamid, le Saltan sctuel. Je n'insieterai pas sur les evéne- ments et les intrigues su moyen desqaels celdi-ci reassit, avec. l'aide de quelquea ministres, a detroner son frore Mourad. Aussitot-monte sur le trone, le premier soin da nouvesu monsrque fut de reléguer son frere su fond du palais de Tcheragan, traneforme en prison, i l'effet de l'isoler lui et tous les membres de sa famille, de toutes relatiops aveo le monde extérieur. Sa mefiance allait jasqa'a leur refuwer leu soine medicsur en che de maladie ; ledr notirriture etait limitee au striot necessaire et ne renfermait rien qui put relever ou même.soutenir leurs forces défaillantes. La mere du Sulsan Mourad, malgre toutes ses prières, ne put obtenir la permission de se faire soigner par un doctear ; il en fut de meme pour ser enfants, dont la plupart sont morte faute de secours mesicaux. Un de ses petite-fils etant mort, son cadavre resta pendant pins de 3 jours exposé et, lofsque Hamid consentit enfin à acoorder l'autorisstion de l'iphamer, - le corps était en pleine de voie deputréfaction. Il fau- drait un.gros volume pour contenir tous les faita snafogues à ceux que je viens de rapporter.

Venons maintenant à la mort da Sultan Mourad. Le lendemain de sa mort on fit cireuler le bruit dans Constantinople qu'il avsit succombe ad poison et que Hamid n'aurait pas été étranger à ce crime. A la reception de cette nouvelle, j'eus recours à an de mes' amis intimes du Palais ef lui demandai de m'informer confidentielle- ment 'si ce brait d'empoisonnement svait an fondement f6el. Mon ami du Palais, se hata de me déolarer que cette nouvelle étsit entièrement fausse. Sa mort n'est pas due à un empoisonnement. Oar s'il avait eu oette intention, Hamid l'aurait exécuté depuis longtemps sans avoir à en rendre compte à personne.

Qaelquefois, et cela lui srrivait.bien rare- ment, quand à bout de patierice, Mourad, se permettait d'élever la voix pour impiorer la clemence de son frère sur le triste sort des siens, Hamid lai faiasit dire d'avoir à ce taire,car il tenait entre ses msins le fetfna de sa mort, délivré par le Cheil-ul-Islam et que à la moindre plainte et en vertu de ce fetfna il le ferait disparaitre' de ce monde sans que personne puisse lui en demander raison. La seule et . véritable cause 'qui ait. . hate la fin da Sultan Mourad doit etre cherchee dans le fait saivant que je vais vous reister.

Il y a environ deux mois, le Palais avait fait eirculer le bruit que la fille du Sultan Mourad, Hadige Sultan, avait des rapporta elandestins avec Kemaleddin Pacha, fils de feu Osmen Pacha Ghaai-qui fat aussitot exite sous le pretexte fallacieur d'avoir donne lieu a ce seandale de la Conr, tandis que la vraie cause de son éloignement de la Capitale et du Palais a'etait du qu'a ses iddey liboralen. Ceste eslomnie fut un coup de foudre pour l'esprit et fe coar du Sultan Mourad, qui des ce moment s'affeissa souis le coup de cette horrible diffamation contre celle qu'il adorait dans sa triste existence; il ne se releva plus de cette secoasse qai ávait ébranlé tout son être et qui bata sa fin. Bientôf la nouvelle de cette odieuse calomnnie parvenait aur oreilles de Hsdige Sultan, qai, pousséa par ane légitime indi- gnation, fit parvenir cette reponse a Hamid: "Ta m'ss foreé d'épouser l'un de tes seor6- taires, et malgre mon refas, tu ss fait célebrer mon mariage contre mon gré et en violation de la loi sacree de l'Islam. Bache cependant que cet homme n's jamais partage ma couche. Comment oses-tu me calomnier en faisant circuler dans le publie le faux bruit de rapports illicites que j'amrais eus avec Kemal'edin Pacha? Je saie encore suasi vierge qae le jour ou je suis sortie da sein de ma mère. Si tu en doute, tu es libre de me faire examiner. O'est avec horrenr que je repousse cette lache calomnie. Je m'attendais à tous les maux de ta erusute, mais jamais l'idee ne ie serait venue a l'espris que tu serais capable de porter tes mains rouges de sang pour soufller ignominieunement le nom, .l'honneur et la vertu de notre famille."
C'est sous l'impression de cette nouvelle que la sante du Sultan Mourad fut défi- nitivement ébranlée, me.dit mon smi.
( à.suivre ).

div.head: QUESTIONS MUNICIPALES
div.p: Service du Tanzim
Un grare inconvenient

A la seance de lundi dernier de la Oom- mission Municipale, communication'a ete donnee anx membres d'une lettre de S.E. le Ministre de l'Interieut informant qq'il approuve la maniere de voir de le Deleg- tion en ce qui concerne la présidenoe da Conseil da Tanzim et qu'il ne voit paa d'ineonvénient à désigner comme président de ce comité, l'Administrateur de la Muni- eipalité.

Il n'est. pad question, bien entendu, d'at- taquer ici la personne de l'administrateur, M. Chataway a tontes nos vympathies ; il B'agit d'une simple question de principe. L'inconvenient de nommer comme prési- dent du Conseil du Tanzim le chet de l'administration est si érident que pous ne comprenons, pss comment il s pu écbap per a la fois a la Delegstion et au Ministere. Il résulte de la composition même du oo- miie. Les membres qui en font partie, sux termes den dectets, sont en effet : 1° Le Gouverneur d'Alezandrie ou son wekil président, 9° un délégué du service seni- taire, 3° l'ingéniear en chef des services de la ville, 4° ua délégue de la Munieipalité et 5° l'ingenieur en chef deu Batimenti de l'Etat. Le conseil ainsi constitu6, com- brenait trois membres iodépendante de l'adminisfration, le gouverneur, le del6. gue municipal et l'ingemieur de l'Etat. Grace au nouveau systeme insugur6, l'ad. miniatrateur devient le président du comité et dispose comme tel der 2 autret voiz, delle de l'ingénieur en chef des terviees de la ville et du délégaé, du service sanitaire. Que devient dans de telles conditiong le role des deux voix independantes qui res- tent, en supposant même qn'elles s'anis- ent; ne sont-etles pas condamnéen d'avanice a assister aux seances en témoine impais- dante?

Voila an resultat deplorable que n'ont certainement pad préva les suteurs de la proposition ni oeux qui lont sanctionnée. L'incon venientse compliqae d'sillears d'in- donsequence. Dans les astributions de l'ad- mhinistrateur, précisées pat le récent projet de réorganisation, il n'est parlé d'auoune présidence, et c'est, croyons nous, au len- demain de la promulgation s'oublier un peu trop que de confier à l'administratear le poste de président du principal service après la Commission et la Délégation.

div.head: THE GARSTIN REPORT
div.byline: * By Sir Hanbury Brown, K.C.M.G., ate In- speetor General of Irrigation in Lower Egypt, anil formerly in Upper Egypt.,
div.p: (Continued)

1l thie winter discharge of the Blue Nile is reserved for the Sudan, as proposed in the Blne book, there, will certainly. be, no winter supply. to spare for the Rayan Reservoir, at aby rate nntil the amount of the winter supply has been increased, by the prevention of loss of water in the . "Sudd".region. Consequently Sit W.Garstin considers thar Mr. Beresford's Bor to-Sobat canal project must come first. Otherwise winter navigation below Assonan will astredly suffer, as the filling of the enlarged ssonan Reservoir will canse a reduetion of 22 million cubie metres a day from the natural ichargeof the river, already rednicedh 20mil- lion zhrongh the transfer of the Blue Nile to the'service of the Sudan .. Sir W. Willcocks other proposal provides."for the filling during ffood, but, instead of a storage of 2 mnliards, 3 milliard's is provided for. It seems to me that, as the winter supply of the river is limited, the project for filling during flodd is the sound one. But, conwidering this project as an alteznative to the Bor channel project, it would be prefer- able, for purposes of comparison, to have before one an estimate for a storage of 2500 million eubic metres, as giving- all that is wanted in Egypt in the following way

Sir W. Willcocks estimates , that his project - would cost. L.E. 2,000,000 if two milliards are stored; and L.E. 2,600,000. if three milliards are sfored. Mr. A. L. Webb, C.M.G., the Inspector General of Irrigation; Upper Fgypt, criticises the proposals in the following words : -"The moditied project, with inlet and outlet channels of sufhcient dimensions-to allow of the Wady Rayan both as a storage reservoir and a flood escape would cost at least L.E. 5,500,000. It is fascinating, and presents no 'engineering difficulties, but-it has its draw- backs. It is costly, it will take ten years to bring into working order, and it must not be forgotten that no one. can know, nor are there any means of. ascertaining, whether it will hold water." Sir W. Garstin lays stress on this, last objection. In reply, to it, Sir W. Willcocka argues thus :- "When the old Lake Moeris, or the presens Fayoum, was full of water, and 63'm. higher than the bottom of the Wadi Rayan, and remnined so for thousands of years, there was. no question of the waters having become salted, or having escaped into the Wady. The Wady was as dry as it is to- dayrand the great inland sea was always fresh. If there had been any! serious intiltration from the ancient Lake Moeris into the Wady Rayan there would have resulted -a considerable lake, "which could not have escaped the notice of the numerous' travellers and writers who visited and described Lake Moeris. No mention was ever made of such a lake."

SiW. Garstin quotes from the report of the Technical Gommission, showing that Sir Benjamin Baker and his colleagues considered there was a danger of serious infiltrations and springs being formed in the Fayoum ; and on account of this fear, Sir W. Garstin considers it "advisable to reserve judgment upon this scheme," and for this reason, and for the sake. of incrgasing the water supply passing Assouan, he considers the project for improving the Bahr-el-Gebel should be given preference over that of the Wadi Rayan. For those who have felt the attraction of the Rayan project, it will be roothing to note that "judgment is reserved," and nothing worse.

We have now passed in review. all the pro- jeets immediately affecting Egypt which are contained in the list of works considered mnost urgent: In the fuller list appear, "Two barrages between Assiout and Kena-L .. E. 2,000,000," nbout which the report says nothing. They would probably be similar, works to the Assiout Barrage, and have similar functions. There have been other works of Nile control discussed of late years, of which no mention is made in the Blue-book, probably because the provision of an ample supply in the river, above the Delta Barrage would fender them annecessary, and would be a preferable alternative. These rnggested works are :
(Concluded.)

It has also been suggested that it would be better to make a barrage somewhere between Beni Souef and Wasta, rather than adapt the Middle Egypt perennial canal to carry the extra supply reqnired by Gizeh.Province and the northern / tracts of Beni Souef. Possibly this suggestion also has died young to give place to a better.

div.head: THE ASSOUAN DAM. DESTRUCTION OF TEMPLES.
div.p: ."F.R.S." writes as follows to the Times. The lettet referied to in our last paragraph was.re produced in our issue of the 12th inst. :-

Some years ago, when the proposal was made fo abmerge Philae and other temples in Nubia, the general sense of indignation at such destruc- tion brought about a change of plans ; and it was tacitly understood that the reproach of such vandalism was not to be borne by England.

Now it is rumoured that this understanding is to be torn up, before any public statement is made as to the steps whioh will be taken, and that the dain at Assouan is to be heightened without further notice or justification. If this is truo, it would be a serjous breach" of what was believed by the publie to be an honourable compromise ; and the public are justified in asking for direct information.
1. Is the Assouan dam to be raised ?
25 Ifrso, what buildings will be. submerged in Nubia T.There is a belief that great slestruc- tion among the few remaining temples that are left in Egype will follow such a course.

8. Will any steps be taken about the many. ancient .buildings which would be ruined it they are submerged 1 Will they all be removed and carefully rebuilt above the levels ,of'this of any future submergence 1

In asking these questions no one impugos the excellent intentions of zealgas engineers. The intentions of Torquemada were excellent to. save men's souls ; the intentions of Robespierre were excellent ; so were those of the Communards. The intentions of Mehemet Aly were excellent when he destroyed temple after temple to build sugar factories and powder magazines rather cheaper. We meet with zealots in all lines, but the destructiye zealot is a public danger. And until the. zealot engineer has publicly proved that/ no iiter- native to his plans is possible, and: that he is not merely cheapening by destruction, he must be classed as a public danger.

The public have heard of several other courses being possible for, storage of the Nile the dam at the Kaibar cataract, (see The Times, October 1), or at other sites. Each of these must be openly discussed and nothing suppressed. And .until there is a clear proof that no'other course is possible for the mer- cantile benefit of Egypt, there ought to be no tampering with the compromise which was believed to have honourably ,closed. the ques- tion at Assouan ..

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN AUTOMATIC TRADNG COMPANY
div.p: Under the. liquidation of this company's affairs Mr. G. Stapylton Barnes, Senior Official Receiver and liquidator, reports that what purports to be a statement.of liabilities and assets of the company was lodged with the Board of Trade on September 9 'last, after Police-court and other proceedings : had been taken against the directors, and after the- directors had been fined for their default in not submitting such statement. The statement, which shows an estimated sur- plus of £22,737 98. 2d., is said to be imper- fect and cannot be accepted as representing the true position of the company. The assets consist of 25,500 shares of El each, fully-paid, in the British and Colonial Automatic Trading Company (Limited), and a book debt of £12,000, due from. the same company. The- skares and book debt are stated by the secret- ary,of the British and Colonial Automatic Trading Company (Limited) to represent .the purchase price payable by that company for the property of the Anglo Egyptian Automatic Trading Company (Limited), under an agree- ment of. August 7, 1903, between the two companies. The secretary adds that the Bri- tish and Colonial Automatic Trading Company (Limited) took possession of, the 'property of the Anglo Egyptian Trading Company (Limit- ed) on September 5, 1903. The Senior Official Receiver also reporte that according to the statutory returns made by the Anglo-Egyptian- Automatic Trading Company (Limited) to the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies 12,852 shares of the company had been issued suhject to payment wholly in cash, that no shares had been issted as fully paid-up otherwise than for cash, that the full amount of the shares hat been called up, and that payment had been received for the whole .amount-viz., £12,852. The Senior Official Receiver states that the only cash which appears in fact to have been received in respect of shares is £500, and that according to the books of the company 12,345 fully paid shares were issued as part payinent for plant, machinery, etc., sold to the company, no agreement for the issue being filed with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies.

div.head: SOCIETY OF "TEMPORARY WIFEHOOD"
div.p: A Moscow lady named Korneskoff has formed an alliance of women "against that male tyranny which imposes on women marriage of a life- time," and has founded a society of "temporary wifehood." The members (says the corres- pondent of the Daily Dispatch) pledge them- selves to abjure the sanctions of the Church, andto "marry only for a preliminary term of five years." A marriage contract will be duly signed, the male partner depositing in a bank a sum equal to a third of his capital, which will revert to the bride and to her children on the union being terminated before the expiry of the stipulated term. At the end of the five years, if the parties desire to continue their union, they must bind themselves for life by the ordinary church ceremony. One "wedding" has already faken place under the auspices of 'the' "Emancipated Women," the bride being the young daughter of the founder of the society, and the bridegroom a doctor whom she had refused to marry on other terms. Instead of to "honour. and obey," the wife swore to "cherish and respeot". her husband,

div.head: MR. CULLEN'S TRAVELS. HIS IMPRESSIONS OF JAPAN
div.p: Mr. Noyman Cullen has given our Cairo Correspondent a most interesting interview on his experiences of Japan. Questioned on the feeling of the European residents in the country, he stated that their sympathies, even if not pro-Russian, are by. no means strongly in favour of Japan. The majority of these residents are suffering more and more from the vigour and efficiency of Japanese compe- tition ; firms which a few years ago.did an immense amount of business.as commission agents Have now to face the competition of branches of great Japanese houses established ih Europe and America, and. the success of the Japanese would inevitably result in a still greater extension, at European .and American expense, of their great commercial influence in China. None the less, all unprejudiced observers were compelled to admit that the Japanese merited their success in arms and in commerce.To their enterprise and hardihood was joined an extraordinary mastery of defail and. organising power. So experienced an authority as Sir Frederick Treves has declared that in their. military hospital arrangements, so far from. having anything to learn, they bave much to teach all other nations. The Japanese, in Mr. Cullen's opinion, do not merely adopt Western civilisation, they adapt it to the needs of theit country, and with their ex- traordinary quickness of perception and com- prehension and their spirit of self-saerifice they may become in a very short time the leading power in the Pacific.

With regard to the criticisms that have been made against -Japanese z commercial morality, Ma. Callen quoted a remark made in his presence by a leading Japanese financier. "These are only growing pains; after all, Japan should' not be, blamed for admitting some unolean things. in the parcel of Western civilisation,"

The world is beginning to realise that "little Japàn' is a nation of 45,000,000 inhabitants; and Mr. Cullen pointed out that expansion is fast becoming an economic. necessity for the country .. The yearly increase amounts to half- a-million, the density of population of the main islands averaged 288 to the square mnile, and though the Northern Island of Vezo or Hokkaido is being colonised, as is Formosa, peither of these territories is likely to draw away such large numbers as Korea will if the Japanese make good their occupation of the kingdom. On every side one sees evidences of industry and efficiency. Iron bridges, cannon, electrical apparatus, etc., are ell being con- structed, and well constructed, in the country, while the new electric tram service of Tokio is a marvel of efficiency. An 8-mile ride at a good speed in a comfortable tram-car seems cheap at a price equivalent to 3 milliemes of Egyptian money. On the other hand, crowding and com- petition have -undoubtedly caused much dis- tress among the working people at Osaka and other manufacturing centres, where a crude Socialism has appeared among the workers. Up to now this has been confined to economic. questions and no anti-dyhastic or anti military movement can be dreamt of, for loyalty to the: Emperor as representative of the State is the religion of Japan.

With regard to: the war, great. numbers of trained men remain in Japan and thousands more are being trained. The tactics of the Japanese -have on the whole been modelled on the teaching of German instructors, but. in dealing with correspondents Lord Kitchener has 'been their model. General Fukushima informed Mr. Cullon. that the interests ;at stake were so enormous. that the War Office felt bound to check the activity of the jour- halisté, much as they regretted disappointing newspapers who had spared no expense in their preparations to describe the campaign. As to the actual conduct of the war,.the stories of atrocities on both sides must not be accepted without very careful investigation. The general opinion among unprejudiced observers was that the war had been extremely fairly and humanely fought. Lnck of preparation, com- missariat frauds, and weakness in good officers- had been the cause of the Russian defeats.

div.head: WILL RUSSIA DRAW UPON CHURCH PROPERTY?
div.p: Some sensation. has been caused.by persis: tent rumours that in certain eventualities the Russian Treasury may draw upon Russian Church property in order to provide funds for the war, It is even rumoured (says a Russian correspondent in the Times) that the: Holy Synod has already been approached with, the suggestion that churches and monasteries should themselves voluntarily offer some of their valuables to the. State. Very large sums could .thus undoubtedly be placed at the disposal of the Treasury, but it is equally certain that any such tampering would be viewed with widespread dismay, and not least from the religious point of view.

div.head: MACEDONIAN GREEKS ARE UP IN ARMS.
div.p: The Macedonian question has entered upon a new phase. Exasperated by the crimes of the Bulgarian revolutionary bands, the Grebks of Macedonia are up in arms, and fighting has taken place.The declared aim of these Bul- garian bands is to mend or end Turkish mis- rule in Macedonia. Their methods, however, do not support their protestations. Authentic records are available to prove that in recent years they have murdered close upon three hundred -Greeks, outmged hundreds more, killed many of their own compatriots, and harassed the Macedonian population generally. The victims have ranged. in station from the peasant to the patriarch, and their only "orime" has been .that they either refused financial assistance to the Bulgarian committee or, as in the case of many of the Greeka, Fesisted sohiem- atio ooerdion,

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves resporsible for the opinions exprossed by our dorrespondentd, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits - freo. discussion.
A COMPLAINT ..
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,-I, the undersigned, desire to bring to the notice of the public, and especially the General Officer Commanding the Army of Occupation, as well as all British regimental officers, that a person named Mansour Salim had already been employed as a waiter to one of the English officers- here in Cairo and was sent away for his misconduct. Then he obtained the contract for washing and ironing of the linen of the battalion stationed at Kasr- el-Nil barracks and not being able to meet the daily disbursements necessary for the work, he came and requested me to join him and provide the requisite capital. I was to pay the amounts necessary from time to time and he was to serve under my orders. I'accepted this arrangement and he remained working with me until I began to find him dishonest. I had advanced him ten pounds to meet current expenses. He did not do so, but, on the contrary, he spent the money in other ways. So, on discovering this, I dissolved our agreement and brought an aetion against Mansour Salim in the Native Tribunal for the recovery of my money and the case was decided in my favor. When the huissier proceeded to Mansour Salim's house he ound nöthing to seize to satisty my just claim in the way of clothes or furniture except what was worth about P.T.40 .. But the huissier discovered at the same time that the fourth part of the house, in which my debtor resided was his property, so I have placed a seizure on this quarter part and the Tribunal has ordered it to be sold. Now I have suc- ceeded in getting myself the contract for the washing and ironing of. the linen of the regi- ment stationed at Kasr-el-Nil Barracks, and Mansour Salim on finding .this has. been writing to the different officers and offering to do the work again at a lesser price, but as he has neither money nor credit anywhere I'am writing through your columns to warn all these whom it. may concern. that he. is only trying to deceive and defraud them. I make this declaration on mny own responsibility and am prepared to stand all consequences of my action in making public Mansour Salim's evil doings through the medium of the English Press.
Signed

div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.

table.head: HORAIRE DES TRAINS A PARTIR DU 3 NOVEMBRE 1904

div.p: N.B. – Ne seront admis dans les deux trains No 3 et 24, que les voyageurs porteurs de billets de 1re et 2e classe seulement et les abonnés à ces deux classes. Le train No 16 ne s'arrêtera pas les Dimanches au garage Cozzika. – Le train No 22 s'arrêtera les Dimances à Massarah au lieu du train No 18.
N.B. Tous les mardis et les jeudis de chaque semaine, pendant la saison théâtrale à l'Opéra Khédivial le dernier train partira de Bab-el-Louk à 12h.45 au lieu de 12h.30.
